children.name: to beat sb in a game, election competition, etc
beat
children.definition: to get more points, votes etc than an opposing team or political party: đánh bại (nhờ điểm, phiếu bầu)
examples: ▪Do you think the Socialists will beat the Liberals in the election?
▪ Brazil beat Italy in the final.
▪ Lewis was a tough boxer, and a hard man to beat.

children.name: beat sb at sth
examples: ▪ My Father used to let me beat him at chess.

children.name: beat sb by 20 points/5 seconds/50 votes etc
examples: ▪The Swedish runner beat the Canadian by just under two seconds.

children.name: beat sb 3-1/84 to 61/etc
examples: ▪The Red Sox beat the Yankees 6-3.

children.name: defeat
children.definition: especially written to get more points, votes etc than an opposing team, person, or political party. Defeat is more formal than beat.: đánh bại (văn viết)
examples: For the sixth consecutive year, Oxford defeated Cambridge today in the annual boat race.
Polk of California was defeated by a Democratic challenger in the last election.

children.name: defeat sb by 20 points/two goals to one etc
examples: Sanchez defeated Dornan by just 984 votes.

children.name: get the better of
children.definition: especially British, spoken to defeat an opponent or team in a game - use this especially about opponents or teams of a similar ability:

children.name: chiến thắng
examples: ▪She’s determined not to let Smith, her fiercest rival, get the better of her.

children.name: be more than a match for
children.definition: to easily beat your opponent in a game, especially when people were not expecting you to:

children.name: quá sức so với người nào đó
examples: ▪I thought I might beat Tracy at tennis but she was more than a match for me.
Tôi nghĩ rằng tôi có thể đánh bại Tracy ở quần vợt nhưng cô ấy là quá sức so với tôi.
▪ The Russian president has once again proved more than a match for his political adversaries.
Tổng thống Nga lại một lần nữa được chứng minh là quá sức so với các đối thủ chính trị của mình.

children.name: to lose a game, war, election, argument, etc
lose
children.definition: to lose a game, competition, fight, or war: thua
examples: ▪ I always lose when I play tennis with my sister.

children.name: lose a game/fight/election etc
examples: ▪ Everyone expected the Democrats to lose the election.
▪ The Chicago Bears lost their eighth game in a row they lost eight games, one after the other.

children.name: lose to
examples: ▪ England lost to Brazil in the final.
▪ He lost his title unexpectedly to a man who is virtually unknown outside boxing circles.

children.name: lose 3-2/by 1 goal/by 10 votes/by 20 points etc
examples: ▪ The Springboks lost by only three points to the All Blacks.
▪ The match was lost 3 to 1.
lose sb the game/competition/election etcbe the reason that sb lost : làm ai thua ...
▪ Many people think that the Democrats’ tax policies lost them the election.

children.name: be beaten
children.definition: to lose a game, competition, or race, often by alargeamount or when you wereexpecting to win: bị đánh bại
examples: ▪ In 37 fights, Lewis has only been beaten once.
▪ Jake sure doesn’t like being beaten.

children.name: be beaten b
examples: ▪ The Barbarians were beaten in the quarter-finals by the Korean side.

children.name: get beaten
examples: ▪ We always seems to get beaten when we play in Europe.

children.name: be defeated
children.definition: to lose animportantordifficultbattle, election, or game: bị đánh bại
examples: ▪ Government forces took control of the town after the rebel forces were defeated.

children.name: be defeated by
examples: ▪ Last night, the Raiders were defeated by a superior team.

children.name: be badly/heavily/decisively defeatedbe very badly defeated bị thất bại nặng nề
examples: ▪ He ran for Congress last year, but was decisively defeated.

children.name: be narrowly defeatedto lose but be very close to winning suýt thắng
examples: ▪ The Democratic Party was narrowly defeated in the general election, and will form a coalition with the Congress party.

children.name: meet your match
children.definition: if a very good player, team etc meets their match, they are beaten by an even better player, team etc, especially after a long period during which they were never beaten: gặp đúng đối thủ
examples: She’s a good player but she’ll meet her match when she plays Sara.

children.name: meet your match in
examples: I slowly started to realize I had met my match in Nigel.

children.name: take a beating
children.definition: to lose very badly in a game of football, tennis etc: thua thảm hại
examples: ‘I hear you took a bit of a beating last night.’ ‘Yeah, we lost 12 -2.’

children.name: to defeat an enemy in war
defeat
children.definition: to completely defeat anenemy’sarmybecause your armed forces are much larger, have better equipment etc:
examples: đánh bại
▪The army was well-trained and well-armed, and had little difficulty defeating the rebels.
Quân đội được đào tạo bài bản và có trang bị vũ khí, và không khó khăn để đánh bại quân nổi dậy.
heavily defeat thất bại nặng nề
▪The Republicans were heavily defeated in the Spanish Civil War.
Những người Cộng hòa đã thất bại nặng nề trong cuộc Nội chiến Tây Ban Nha.
defeatverb[ T ] đánh thắng; đánh bại
to win a victory over someone in a fight, war or competition
_Napoleon was defeated by the Duke ofWellingtonat the battle ofWaterloo.
_If we can defeat the Italian team, we'll be through to the final.

children.name: overwhelm
children.definition: to completely defeat anenemy’sarmybecause your armed forces are much larger, have better equipment etc:

children.name: lấn áp, áp đảo
examples: ▪Napoleon’s army was strong enough to overwhelm nearly any potential enemy.
Quân đội Napoleon đủ mạnh để lấn áp gần như bất kỳ kẻ thù tiềm tàng nào.
▪ With its greatly superior technology, the government forces completely overwhelmed the rebels.
Với công nghệ vượt trội của mình, lực lượng chính phủ đã hoàn toàn áp đảo các phiến quân.

children.name: annihilate
children.definition: to completely defeat anenemy’sarmyin a war and to destroy all their armed forces:

children.name: tiêu diệt
examples: ▪After a long and bloody battle the army succeeded in annihilating Seged’s forces.
Sau một trận chiến dài và đẫm máu, quân đội đã thành công trong việc tiêu diệt lực lượng của Seged.
▪ In 1945 Japan was helpless, with its military power annihilated.
Năm 1945, Nhật Bản bất lực trước việc sức mạnh quân sự của mình đã bị tiêu diệt.

children.name: rout
children.definition: to completely defeat an enemy’s army in battle:

children.name: bị đánh bại hoàn toàn
examples: ▪The general was killed and his armies were routed in a magnificent cavalry charge.
Tướng quân bị giết còn đội quân của ông ta thì bại trận hoàn toàn dưới sự tiến công hào hùng của đoàn kị binh.

children.name: bring sb to their knees
children.definition: bring somebody to their knees  to cause the final defeat of an enemy, especially after a long war, so that they are too weak to fight back: nhận lấy thất bại
examples: ▪The disastrous Battle of the Boyne finally brought the Catholics to their knees.
Trận đánh tàn bạo của Boyne cuối cùng đã khiến những người Công giáo nhận lấy thất bại.
▪ After years of trench warfare, the Kaiser’s army had finally been brought to its knees.
Sau nhiều năm chiến hào, quân đội Kaiser cuối cùng đã nhận lấy thất bại.

children.name: conquer
children.definition: to completely defeat the armed forces of an enemy country, with the result that you have complete control over it:
examples: chinh phục
▪ Sailors travelled to the New World with the urge to conquer and explore.
Những thủy thủ đi đến Thế giới Mới với sự thôi thúc để chinh phục và khám phá.
▪ Julius Caesar conquered Gaul, which we know today as France.
Julius Caesar chinh phục Gaul, nơi mà ngày nay chúng ta gọi là Pháp.
conquerverb[ T ] xâm chiếm;chinh phục
to take control or possession of foreign land, or a group of people, by force
_The Spanish conquered theNew Worldin the 16th century.
_The English were conquered by theNormansin 1066.

children.name: when you are likely to lose
be losing
children.definition: to be in a position where you are likely to lose a game, competition, election or war because you are not doing as well as your opponent: đang thất thế
examples: ‘Is Joachim winning?’ ‘No, he’s losing.’
be losing the game/war etc
It can be difficult not to show your frustration when you’re losing the match.
be losing 3--1/by 15 points/by 2 goals etc
‘What’s the score?’ ‘We’re losing 3 -- nil.’

children.name: be behind
children.definition: to be losing a game, competition, or election: bị bỏ lại
examples: be behind by two goals/by10 points etc
The opinion polls show that the Republicans are behind by 3%.
be 10 points/a goal etc behind
‘How are we doing?’ ‘We’re 10 points behind, I’m afraid.’
be a long way behind/be way behindbe losing by a large amount
Although we only had a short break, we were a long way behind the front runners.
The Eagles are way behind. We’ll never win at this rate.

children.name: be trailing
children.definition: trail to be losing a game or competition, or election - used especially in news reports: tụt đằng sau
examples: Penn State trail West Virginia by only 1 point.

children.name: trail 3--0/by 10 points/by 8 votes etc
examples: Sweden was trailing by 2 games to 1.
With his team trailing 72--78, the manager was forced to bring back his star player.

children.name: trail behind
examples: These two top drivers have left the others trailing behind.
Labour trailed third, behind the Conservative and Liberal parties.

children.name: outsider
children.definition: a person or team that is not expected to win: yếu thế
examples: The defending champion was beaten by an outsider in the first round.
Smith, a little-known outsider with limited political experience, came from behind to score a surprise victory.

children.name: rank outsidersb with a very small chance of winning UK
examples: He started as a no-hoper -- a rank outsider for the title.

children.name: to beat sb very easily in a game, election, competition, etc
/slaughter/massacre/annihilate
children.definition: to completely beat someone in a game, competition, election etc:
examples: đè bẹp, tàn sát, giết chết, huỷ diệt..
▪Wow, the Raiders just slaughtered the Seahawks again.
Wow, Raiders đã vừa tàn sát Seahawks một lần nữa.
▪ The party strategy was to form an alliance to crush the communists.
Chiến lược của đảng là hình thành một liên minh để đè bẹp các cộng sản.

children.name: clobber/hammer/cream [US]
children.definition: to beat someone very easily in a game, competition, election etc: đánh bại hoàn toàn, đè bẹp dễ dàng
examples: ▪We’ve been clobbered twice now by Central High’s basketball team.
Cho tới bây giờ chúng tôi đã hai lần bị đội bóng rổ của Central High dễ dàng đè bẹp.
▪ Chicago hammered Boston in an away game on Saturday.
Chicago đánh bại hoàn toàn Boston trong trận đấu trên sâ khách hôm thứ Bảy.

children.name: ▪ ‘How’d the game go?’ ‘We creamed 'em!’
examples: 'Trận đấu như thế nào?' "Chúng tôi đã đè bẹp họ!

children.name: rout
children.definition: especially British to beat an opposing team or political party easily and completely: dễ dàng đánh bại hoàn toàn (Anh)
examples: ▪The Australians have once again routed the English cricket team.
Người Úc đã một lần nữa dễ dàng đánh bại hoàn toàn đội tường cầu của Anh.

children.name: wipe the floor with sb
children.definition: wipe the floor with somebody informal to defeat someone completely in an argument or competition: hạ đo ván ai đó
examples: ▪I’d think twice before I started a fight with him - he’d wipe the floor with me!
Tôi nghĩ hai lần trước khi bắt đầu cuộc chiến với anh ấy - anh ấy hạ đo ván tôi!

children.name: outplay
children.definition: to play much better than an opponent or team in a game and beat them easily: dễ dàng vượt qua, giỏi hơn

children.name: ▪Ohio outplayed Michigan, especially in the fourth quarter, winning by 14 points
examples: Ohio dễ dàng vượt qua Michigan, đặc biệt là trong phần tư thời gian thứ 4, với 14 điểm.

children.name: admit defeat
children.definition: admit/accept defeat to stop playing, fighting, or trying to succeed because you know you will lose, especially after you have struggled to succeed for a long time: chấp nhận thất bại
examples: The four climbers were eventually forced to admit defeat when weather conditions made it impossible to continue.
She simply refuses to accept defeat, no matter how bad things seem.
After several attempts to untie the knot, I admitted defeat and cut through it with a knife.

children.name: give in
children.definition: to stop playing, fighting, arguing etc because you know that you are not good enough to win: bỏ cuộc
examples: Marie’s stubborn, and she doesn’t give in easily.

children.name: give in to
examples: I figured if we gave in to them this time, they’d be back for another fight.
In the end, I had to give in to dad -- he’s usually right anyway.

children.name: concede
children.definition: to admit that you are not going to win a battle, argument, or game because you are not strong enough or good enough to win: thừa nhậnthua
examples: Eventually, the chairman was forced to concede and announce his resignation.
‘Sam, you have to apologise to her’ -- ‘I know,’ Sam conceded grudgingly.
The Georgian forces defended the capital but were finally obliged to concede.

children.name: concede defeatadmit you are defeated
examples: Matthew kept on arguing his point, unwilling to concede defeat.
In May 1949, Stalinconceded defeatand reopened land access to Berlin.

children.name: concede to
examples: We both had a point, but neither of us would concede to the other.

children.name: to beat sb by using your intelligence
outwit
children.definition: /outsmart  to get an advantage over someone that you are fighting or competing against, by using clever tricks and planning rather than by force: đánh lừa, khôn ngoan
examples: ▪We can’t fight them. We’ll just have to try and outsmart them.
Chúng ta không thể đánh lừa họ. Chúng ta sẽ phải thử và đánh lừa chúng.
▪ None of the thieves wanted to admit that they had been outwitted by a couple of teenagers.
Không ai trong số những tên trộm muốn thừa nhận rằng họ đã bị một cặp thanh thiếu niên đánh lừa.

children.name: be too clever/smart [especially US] for
children.definition: if you are too clever or too smart for someone, they have tried to trick you but you realized what they were doing and stopped them succeeding:
examples: ▪Molly tried to hide the presents but the children were too clever for her and found them within minutes

children.name: defeat
children.definition: a situation in which a person, army, political party etc is defeated:
examples: ▪ After his third successive election defeat he decided to retire from politics.

children.name: suffer a defeat
examples: ▪ In the last game of the season they suffered a humiliating defeat, losing 7-0 to Real Madrid.

children.name: rout
children.definition: a situation in which a person, army, political party etc is easily defeated: thất bại (dễ dàng như dạo chơi, ăn tiệc)
examples: ▪The game was a rout, with the home team winning by 10 goals to nil.

children.name: drubbing
children.definition: a situation in which a person, team, political party etc is defeated badly: thảm bại
examples: ▪Gramm’s drubbing by Davis in the California primary has badly hurt his campaign.

children.name: take a drubbing
examples: ▪The Lions took a drubbing from the Eagles last night, losing 58-37.

children.name: defeat
children.definition: when a person, team, or army is defeated in a game, competition, election, battle etc:
examples: sự thất bại
▪ It was the Christian Democratic Party’s fourth successive electoral defeat.
defeat of sự thất bại của
▪ the defeat of Napoleon at the battle of Waterloo
somebody’s defeat of somebodythe fact that one person or team defeats another sự thật bại của ai trước ai
▪ Scotland’s defeat of Spain
Scotland đánh bại Spain
somebody’s defeat by somebodythe fact that one person or team is defeated by another sự thất bại của ai bởi ai
▪ Mr Taylor blamed bad publicity for his defeat by Mr Jones.
a crushing/humiliating/resounding defeat sự thất bại nhục nhã
▪ The captain offered no excuses for his team’s humiliating defeat.
▪ The New York Times described the withdrawal of troops as a resounding defeat for the government.
suffer a defeat : bị thất bại cay đắng
▪ She retired from the sport after suffering a series of humiliating defeats.

children.name: succumb
children.definition: verbformal thua, không chịu nổi, không chống nổi

children.name: to lose the determination to oppose something; to accept defeat
examples: _The town finally succumbed last week after being pounded with heavy artillery for more than two months.
_I'm afraid I succumbedtotemptation and had a piece of cheesecake.

children.name: _I felt sure it would only be a matter of time before he succumbedtomy charms
fall
children.definition: nounDEFEATthất bại, thất thủ
examples: [ C usually singular ]the fact of being defeated or losing your power
_the fall ofRome
_The army took control of the city after the president's fallfrompower.

children.name: fall
children.definition: verbfell,fallenBE DEFEATEDthất bại, thất thủ

children.name: fall
children.definition: verbfell,fallenBE DEFEATED thất bại, thất thủ
